cookiesOn: Cookies on Make a lasting power of attorney
cookiesContent:
We use some essential cookies to make this service work.

We’d also like to use analytics cookies so we can understand how you use the service and make improvements.
newServiceContent: This is a new service – your feedback will help us to improve it.
urModeContent: This is a prototype – this is not a real service.
serviceName: Make and register a lasting power of attorney (LPA)
startContent:
You can make a lasting power of attorney (LPA) using our online service.

If you want to, you can ask someone else to use the service for you, for example a family member, friend or solicitor. You will still need to make all the decisions about what goes on the LPA.

We’ll save the LPA as you progress so you do not need to complete it in one go. You can sign out at any time and come back later.

It costs £82 to apply to register an LPA.

Information you’ll need

You may find it useful to gather some information before you start.

As well as your details, you’ll need the names, addresses and dates of birth of:

  • the attorneys
  • the replacement attorneys, if you decide to have any

You’ll also need the name and address of your certificate provider.

Documents, equipment and other things you’ll need

You’ll also need:

  • a debit or credit card to pay the application fee
  • a mobile phone, so we can text you a security code
  • documents or information to prove your identity
What you need to prove your identity

When you make an LPA, we need to check your identity. We do this to protect you and prevent fraud.

You can prove your identity by:

  • entering details from your passport or driving licence
  • entering details from, and uploading a photo of, a recent payslip or P60
  • signing in to your Government Gateway, Department for Work and Pensions, or online banking account, and letting us confirm your details with those organisations
  • taking documents to a Post Office
  • asking a professional (like a teacher, civil servant or solicitor) to confirm your identity
openGovernmentLicenceContent: All content is available under the Open Government Licence v3.0, except where otherwise stated
combinedLegalTerm: property and affairs and personal welfare
otherNames: Any other names you’re known by (optional)
dateOfBirthIsUnder18: You are under 18. I understand that I must be at least 18 on the date I sign the LPA, otherwise the LPA will be rejected.
dateOfBirthIsOver100: By saving this section, you confirm that the person is more than 100 years old. If not, please change the date.
errorMobile: {{.Label}} must be a UK mobile number, like 07700 900 982 or +44 7700 900 982
errorEmail: {{.Label}} must be in the correct format, like name@example.com

cantFindTheirAddressInList: I can’t find their address in the list

imHelping: I’m helping someone else fill in the LPA form
whichTypeOfLpaToMake: Which type of LPA do you want to make?
whichTypeOfLpaToMakeContent:
There are 2 types of LPA. You can make an LPA that covers decisions about your:

  • money, finances and any property you own
  • health care, medical treatment and personal welfare

You can have one or both types of LPA.

They do not have to be made at the same time and you can reuse any information you enter to make other LPAs later.

You can choose different people to be your attorneys for each LPA.

Find out more about the 2 types of LPAs
theTypeOfLpaToMake: the type of LPA to make
lpaTypePfaHumanised: An LPA that covers decisions about my money, finances and property
lpaTypePfaHint: In legal terms, this is called a ‘property and affairs’ LPA. You may also hear it called a ‘property and financial affairs’ LPA
lpaTypeHwHumanised: An LPA that covers decisions about my health care, medical treatment and personal welfare
lpaTypeHwHint: In legal terms, this is called a ‘personal welfare’ LPA. You may also hear it called a ‘health and welfare’ LPA
taskListHelpContent:
There’s help included with every question, and you can also read our full guide to making an LPA.

You may want to look at our before you begin help page. It explains the decisions you have to make about your LPA and the information you’ll need to provide.

We’ll save the LPA as you progress - you don’t need to complete it in one go. You can sign out at any time and come back later.
chooseWhenTheLpaCanBeUsed: Choose when your LPA can be used
checkAndSendToYourCertificateProvider: Check and send to your certificate provider
confirmYourIdentityAndSign: Confirm your identity and sign the LPA
changeDOBLinkText: Change date of birth for {{ .FirstNames }} {{ .LastName }}
doYouWantToAddAnotherAttorney: Do you want to add another original attorney?
yesToAddAnotherReplacementAttorney: yes to add another replacement attorney
doYouWantToRemove: Are you sure you want to remove {{ .FirstNames }} {{ .LastName }}?
yesToRemoveReplacementAttorney: yes to remove the replacement attorney
doYouWantToRemovePersonToNotify: Are you sure you want to remove this person to notify?
doYouWantToRemoveReplacementAttorney: Are you sure you want to remove this replacement attorney?
whoWouldYouLikeToBeTheAttorneys: Who would you like to choose as your attorneys?
whoWouldYouLikeToBeTheAttorneysDetailsCo:
Your attorneys are the people who’ll be able to help you make decisions about your finances, if you ever want or need their help in the future.

It’s important that you choose people you trust to respect your wishes and act in your best interests.

You can have more than 1 attorney. Most people have between 1 and 3.

An attorney must:

  • be aged 18 or over
  • have mental capacity (be able to make decisions)

Someone cannot be an attorney if they are:

  • bankrupt or have a debt relief order
  • on the Disclosure and Barring Service barred list (someone is normally put on this list if they have a criminal conviction or caution that means they’re not allowed to work with vulnerable people)

You’ll be asked if you would like to add replacement attorneys in a separate question. They step in if your original attorneys are unable or unwilling to continue.

Find out more about attorneys
attorneyDateOfBirthIsUnder18: This attorney is under 18 years old. You will not be able to finish making this LPA until they are 18.
wantReplacementAttorneys: Do you want any replacement attorneys?
replacementAttorneysStepIn: Replacement attorneys step in if one of your original attorneys dies or has to step down from the role.

replacementAttorneysStepInExplanation.one: Having replacement attorneys is optional. However, having 1 or more helps make sure your LPA will keep working if {{ .AttorneysFullNames }} (your original attorney) has to step down.
replacementAttorneysStepInExplanation.other: Having replacement attorneys is optional. However, having 1 or more helps make sure your LPA will keep working if {{ .AttorneysFullNames }} (your original attorneys) have to step down.

replacementAttorneyRequirements: A replacement attorney must meet the same requirements as an original attorney. This includes being 18 or over.
findOutMoreAboutReplacementAttorneysCont: Find out more about replacement attorneys
noReplacementAttorneys: No, I do not want replacement attorneys
whenCanYourAttorneysUseYourLpa: When can your attorneys use your LPA
whenYourAttorneysCanUseYourLpa: When your attorneys can use your LPA
youCanDecideHeader: You can decide whether you want your attorney to be able to use the LPA as soon as it’s registered or only if you lose mental capacity.
asSoonAsRegisteredTitle: As soon as the LPA is registered

asSoonAsRegisteredIntro.one: Most people choose this option as it’s the most practical. It means {{ .AttorneysFullNames }} (your attorney) can use the LPA:
asSoonAsRegisteredIntro.other: Most people choose this option as it’s the most practical. It means {{ .AttorneysFullNames }} (your attorneys) can use the LPA:

asSoonAsRegisteredContent:
• when you have mental capacity, but only if you give them permission to do something
  • if you lose mental capacity

This option is useful in case there are times in the future when you’re able to make your own decisions, but need help with certain things. For example, if it ever becomes difficult for you to visit the bank or talk on the phone, you might ask your attorneys to use your LPA to deal with certain organisations on your behalf.
afterLosingCapacityContent:
Only if you lose mental capacity

This option means {{ .AttorneysFirstNames }} can only use the LPA if you have lost mental capacity.

afterLosingCapacityExample.one: Be careful, as this can make the LPA a lot less useful. Each time {{ .AttorneysFirstNames }} tries to use the LPA, they might be asked to prove that you do not have mental capacity.
afterLosingCapacityExample.other: Be careful, as this can make the LPA a lot less useful. Each time {{ .AttorneysFirstNames }} try to use the LPA, they might be asked to prove that you do not have mental capacity.

whenDoYouWantAttorneysToUse.one: When do you want {{ .AttorneysFirstNames }} to be able to use the LPA?
whenDoYouWantAttorneysToUse.other: When do you want your attorneys to be able to use the LPA?

onlyWhenIDoNotHaveMentalCapacity: Only when I do not have mental capacity
restrictionsOnYourAttorneysPowerTitle: Restrict the decisions your attorneys can make
restrictionsOnYourAttorneysPowerContent:
This optional section lets you add extra information for your attorneys, to guide the decisions they can make on your behalf. We call this adding ‘restrictions and conditions’ to your LPA.

What you say here will tell your attorneys things they:

  • must do (‘restrictions’)
  • can only do in certain circumstances (‘conditions’)

You do not have to add restrictions or conditions to your LPA. You may prefer to talk to your attorneys about your wishes, rather than writing them into your LPA.

There are legal rules about what you cannot tell your attorneys to do. It’s important that you word any restrictions and conditions clearly and carefully. Read our guidance on writing restrictions and conditions.
restrictionExamplesContent:
Example restrictions: things the attorneys must not do

  • ‘My attorneys must not sell my home.’

Example restrictions: things your attorneys can only do in certain circumstances

  • ‘My attorneys must not sell my home unless, in my doctor’s opinion, I can no longer live independently.’
restrictionsHint: If you do not want to add any restrictions and conditions, leave the box empty.
restrictionsTooLong: Restrictions must be 10,000 or fewer characters
whoDoYouWantToBeCertificateProviderTitle: Who do you want to be your certificate provider?
whoDoYouWantToBeCertificateProviderGuida:
A certificate provider is an independent person who talks to you to check you understand your LPA and want to make it.

Most people choose a friend, neighbour or colleague to be their certificate provider.
whatYourCertificateProviderHasToDo:
What your certificate provider has to do

Your certificate provider has to:

  • read your LPA once you’ve finished making it
  • meet you in person to talk about your LPA in private
  • witness you signing your LPA

We’ll then ask your certificate provider to:

  • confirm their identity
  • confirm they’ve discussed your LPA with you
  • tell us if they have any concerns about your LPA - for example, if they think someone is pressuring you to make it

We call this ‘providing a certificate’. They can do this using our online service or a paper form.

If we ever have any concerns about your LPA, we may ask your certificate provider to tell us more about the conversation they had with you.
whoToChooseAsYourCertificateProvider:
Who to choose as your certificate provider

You can choose either:

  • someone you’ve known well for at least 2 years, for example, a friend or neighbour (but not a relative)
  • a doctor, lawyer or another professional with the skills to check whether you understand your LPA

Choose someone:

  • you’re comfortable having an open, honest conversation with
  • who will speak up if they think something is wrong

They’ll need to have their own mobile phone.
whoCannotBeACertificateProvider:
Who cannot be a certificate provider

Your certificate provider cannot be:

  • under 18 years old
  • an attorney on your LPA
  • related to you or {{ .AttorneysFirstNames }} (this includes step-relations, in-laws, husbands, wives, partners, boyfriends and girlfriends)
  • a business partner or employee of you or {{ .AttorneysFirstNames }}
  • someone who works for a care home where you live, or their relative
detailsYoullNeedAboutYourCertificateProv:
Details you’ll need about your certificate provider

You’ll need their:

  • full name
  • date of birth
  • mobile phone number
  • email or postal address

Find out more about certificate providers, and who can and cannot take on the role.
certificateProviderDetailsHint: Remember, your certificate provider must be 18 or over. They cannot be a member of your family (this includes step-relations and in-laws) or of the attorneys’ families.
certificateProviderDobContext: We need your certificate provider’s date of birth to check they are over 18.
certificateProviderMobileContext: We need your certificate provider’s mobile number so we can send them a code to use when they witness you signing your LPA.
donorAndCertificateProviderShareLastname:
Your certificate provider’s last name is the same as yours or very similar. Please check that they are not any of the following as these people cannot be your certificate provider:
  • a member of your family (this includes step-relations and in-laws) or of the attorneys’ families
    •
  • a spouse or partner
    •

How would your certificate provider prefer to carry out their role?

onlineAndByEmailHint: We can process your LPA application quicker if your certificate provider chooses this option.

feeCoversExamples:
• checking your identity and {{.CpFirstNames}} {{.CpLastName}}’s identity - we do this to protect you and prevent fraud
  • checking and processing your LPA application
lowIncome: If you have a low income or get certain means-tested benefits, you can apply to pay a lower fee or no fee
qualifyingForReduction: Find out more about qualifying for a reduction

iveCheckedThisLpa: I’ve checked this LPA and do not want to make any changes

whatHappensIfIChange: What happens if I need to make changes later?
whatHappensIfIChangeDetails:
If you want to change your LPA after you’ve had the conversation with your certificate provider, you can.

After you’ve made the changes, you’ll need to have the conversation with your certificate provider again, so you can talk about the updated LPA.
onceYouClickConfirmWarning: Once you click the confirm button, you will not be able to make any more changes.
paymentConfirmationContent:
You have successfully paid for your property and affairs LPA.

We’ve sent you an email to confirm we’ve received your LPA application fee.

If the email has not arrived in a few minutes, check your spam folder.
readAndCheckYourLpa: You must read and check your LPA carefully before you sign it.
whatHappensIfIWantToMakeChanges: What happens if I want to make changes after I’ve signed?
iHaveReadAndCheckedThisLpa: I have read and checked this LPA
iConfirmIMadeThisLpaOfMyOwnFreeWill: I confirm that I made this LPA of my own free will
typeSignatureCode: Type your signature code to sign
iHaventReceivedSignatureCode: I haven’t received a signature code
signYourLpaHeader: Signing the LPA is an important and powerful legal step.
bySigningIConfirm: By signing my {{ .LpaType}} LPA, I confirm all of the following:
iHaveReadLpa: I have read my LPA or have had it read to me. This includes my legal rights and responsibilities.
iGiveAttorneysAuthority: I give my attorneys authority to make decisions about my {{ .LpaType }}, including when I cannot act for myself because I do not have mental capacity.

iHaveChosenNPeopleToNotify.one: I have chosen to notify 1 person about my LPA.
iHaveChosenNPeopleToNotify.other: I have chosen to notify {{ .PluralCount }} people about my LPA.

iHaveNotChosenToNotifyAnyone: I have chosen not to notify anyone about my LPA.
infoIProvidedCanBeUsedByOpg: The information I’ve provided can be used by the Office of the Public Guardian when carrying out its duties.
whenYouTickAndClick: When you tick these boxes and select ‘Submit my signature’ you are legally signing your LPA.
wantToApply: I want to apply to register this LPA
howTickingActsAsSignature: How ticking the boxes acts as your legal signature
howTickingActsAsSignatureContent:
Electronic signatures are legally recognised in England and Wales. They make it easier for you to sign documents online.

By ticking both boxes and selecting ‘Submit my signature’, you are providing your legal signature. This is just as safe and legally binding as signing your LPA by hand.
bothBoxesToSignAndApply: You must select both boxes to sign and apply to register your LPA
iWantToSignThisLpa: I want to sign this LPA
witnessYourSignatureContent:
We now need {{ .CpFullName }}, your certificate provider to confirm that they are with you and have witnessed you signing your LPA.

  1. When you press continue, we’ll send {{ .CpFirstNames }} a text message containing a unique code
  2. {{ .CpFirstNames }} will need to type in this code on the next screen
witnessCodeTimeWarning: When {{ .CpFirstNames }} receives this code, it is valid for 30 minutes. Please use the code within this time.
selectYourIdentityOptions: Select how you will confirm your identity
selectWhichDocumentYouWillUse: Select which document you will use to confirm your identity
pleaseSelectOneFormOfIdentity: Please select one form of identity from this list
yourOneLoginHint: We’ll ask you to sign in to your GOV.UK One Login account so we can confirm your name, address and date of birth. We will not see any other information about you
postOfficeEasyIDHint: Post Office EasyID is a secure digital app that lets you confirm your identity online. We’ll confirm your name, address and date of birth through Post Office EasyID. We will not see any other information Post Office EasyID holds about you.
yourPassportHint: This must be your current passport or one that expired less than 10 years ago. Your name on your passport must be the same as on your LPA.
biometricResidencePermitHint: This must be your current BRP. The name on your BRP must be the same as on your LPA.
drivingLicencePhotocardHint: This must be your full, current licence or one that expired less than 10 years ago. Your name and address on your licence must be the same as on your LPA.
drivingLicencePaperHint: This must be your full, current licence or one that expired less than 10 years ago. Your name and address on your licence must be the same as on your LPA.
aBankAccountHint: We will not access any details from your bank account apart from your name, address and date of birth
iDoNotHaveEitherOfTheseAccounts: I do not have either of these types of accounts
iDoNotHaveAnyOfTheseTypesOfIdentity: I do not have any of these identity documents
weWillAdviseOnOtherWays: We will advise on other ways you can confirm your identity.
whichDocumentYouWillUse: which document you will use to confirm your identity
yourChosenIdentityOptionsContent: You told us that you have the following things to confirm your identity:
whenYouAreReadyToCompleteTheIdentityConf: When you are ready to complete the identity confirmation checks, please press continue.
identifyYourselfWithYoti: Identify yourself with the Yoti app
yourIdentityConfirmedWithYoti: Your identity details confirmed with Yoti
yourIdentityNotConfirmedWithYoti: Your identity details could not be confirmed with Yoti
yourIdentityConfirmedWithOneLogin: Your identity details confirmed with GOV.UK One Login
yourIdentityNotConfirmedWithOneLogin: Your identity details could not be confirmed with GOV.UK One Login
enterUniqueCodeHint: {{ .CpFirstName }}, please type in the code we have sent you, to prove that you are with {{ .DonorFullName }} and have witnessed them sign their LPA.
cpNotReceivedCodeLink: {{ .CpFirstName }} has not received a text message with the code
witnessCodeDoesNotMatch: The code you entered is incorrect, please check it and try again
theCodeWeSentCertificateProvider: The code we sent to the certificate provider
nextStepsList:
1. We’ll contact {{ .CpFirstNames }} and ask them to confirm their identity. They also need to sign your LPA to confirm they’ve discussed it with you. We call this ‘providing a certificate’.
  2. We’ll then contact {{ .AttorneysFullNames }} and ask them to sign your LPA as your attorneys.
  3. Once the attorneys have signed, your LPA will automatically be sent to us to be checked and registered. If we find any problems with your LPA, we’ll contact you.
  4. The law says we then have to wait 4 weeks before registering your LPA. This is in case anyone wants to object to your LPA’s registration.
  5. We’ll register your LPA.
weWillEmailYou: We’ll email you at each step to update you with the progress of your LPA’s registration. You can also track progress by logging into this service.
signIn4WeeksWarning: {{ .CpFirstNames }} and your attorneys must sign your LPA by {{ .AttorneysAndCpSigningDeadline }}. If they do not sign by this date, you will have to meet with {{ .CpFirstNames }} and sign your LPA again.
myLastingPowersOfAttorneyHint: On this page you will find all your in-progress and registered LPAs.
youCanCreateANewLpa: You can create a new LPA or re-use the details of an LPA to make another one, using the ‘Options’ button
howShouldAttorneysMakeDecisions: How should your attorneys make decisions?
jointlyAndSeverallyHint:
Your attorneys can make decisions together or on their own.

This means your attorneys can share tasks and responsibilities. It also means that if one of your attorneys is unable to act, decisions can still be made without them. Most people choose this option as it’s the most practical.

In legal terms, this is known as your attorneys acting ‘jointly and severally’.
jointlyHintAttorneys:
All your attorneys must agree on every decision, however big or small.

This means if one of your attorneys can no longer act, none of your other attorneys will be able to act either, unless you state otherwise in your restrictions. It also means that if your attorneys cannot agree on a decision, it cannot be made without going to court.

In legal terms, this is known as your attorneys working ‘jointly’.
jointlyAndSeverallyMixedHumanised: Some decisions must be made together
jointlyAndSeverallyMixedHint:
All your attorneys must agree on some decisions but can make other decisions on their own. You must state which decisions need to be agreed together.

In legal terms, this is known as your attorneys working ‘jointly for some decisions, and jointly and severally for other decisions’.
decisionDetailsHint: Please tell us which decisions your attorneys must make together. Take a look at the guidance for examples if your attorneys will be making decisions together.
howAttorneysShouldMakeDecisions: how the attorneys should make decisions
howReplacementAttorneysShouldMakeDecisio: how the replacement attorneys should make decisions
jointlyReplacementWarning: Replacement attorneys are an important backup when attorneys are appointed to act jointly.
jointlyReplacementWarningContent:
If you do not appoint any replacement attorneys and one of the original attorneys dies or can no longer act, the LPA will stop working.

If you appoint replacement attorneys and one of the original attorneys dies or can no longer act:

  • ALL the original attorneys will be replaced by the replacement attorneys, unless you state otherwise in your instructions
  • the original attorneys will not be able to make any decisions on your behalf anymore
mixedReplacementWarning: You appointed your attorneys to act jointly for some decisions, and jointly and severally for others.
mixedReplacementWarningContent:
This means that if an original attorney dies or can no longer act:

  • all the replacement attorneys step in and take over making the joint decisions
  • the remaining original attorneys will not be able to make the joint decisions anymore, unless you state otherwise in your instructions
  • the replacement and remaining original attorneys can make all other decisions together or individually
whoWouldYouLikeToBeTheReplacementAttorne: Who would you like to be your replacement attorneys?
doYouWantToAddAnotherReplacementAttorney: Do you want to add another replacement attorney?
howShouldReplacementAttorneysMakeDecisio: How should the replacement attorneys make decisions?
Your choice here is very important as it affects how your LPA can be used. Whichever option you choose, your replacement attorneys must always act in your best interests.
jointlyAndSeverallyHintReplacementAttorn: Replacement attorneys can make decisions on their own or together. Most people choose this option because it’s the most practical.
jointlyHintReplacementAttorneys: Replacement attorneys must agree unanimously on every decision, however big or small. If one replacement attorney can no longer act, the others will not be able to act either, unless you states otherwise in your instructions.
jointlyAndSeverallyMixedHintReplacementA: Replacement attorneys must agree unanimously on some decisions, but can make others on their own. You must state which decisions need to be agreed unanimously.
howReplacementAttorneysShouldStepIn: How replacement attorneys should step in
howYourReplacementAttorneysShouldStepIn: How your replacement attorneys should step in
howShouldYourReplacementAttorneysStepIn: How should your replacement attorneys step in?
howShouldReplacementAttorneysStepInDetai:
You can choose when your replacement attorneys step in and in what order.

Once they’ve stepped in, the replacement attorneys will be able to make any decision jointly and severally along with the remaining original attorneys.

Most donors choose for all the replacement attorneys to step in together as soon as 1 of the original attorneys can no longer act. However, if you would prefer the replacement attorneys to step in later or in a specific order, select 1 of the other 2 options.
whenOneCanNoLongerAct: As soon as one of the original attorneys can no longer act, all the replacement attorneys should step in together
whenNoneCanNoLongerAct: When none of the original attorneys can act, all the replacement attorneys should step in together
otherWayHint: Describe below how you would like this to happen. Be careful - the more specific the instructions, the greater the chance that they will not be able to be followed. If in doubt, seek legal advice. Not sure what to put?
whenYourReplacementAttorneysStepIn: when your replacement attorneys should step in
detailsOfWhenToStepIn: details of when your replacement attorneys should step in
jointly-and-severally:
Your attorneys can make decisions together or on their own.

In legal terms, this is known as your attorneys working ‘jointly and severally’.
jointly:
Your attorneys must make and agree all decisions together.

In legal terms, this is known as your attorneys working ‘jointly’
mixed:
Your attorneys must make certain decisions together.

In legal terms, this is known as your attorneys working ‘jointly for some decisions and jointly and severally for others’.
replacement-jointly-and-severally:
Your replacement attorneys can make decisions together or on their own.

In legal terms, this is known as your replacement attorneys working ‘jointly and severally’.
replacement-jointly:
Your replacement attorneys must make and agree all decisions together.

In legal terms, this is known as your replacement attorneys working ‘jointly’
replacement-mixed:
Your replacement attorneys must make certain decisions together.

In legal terms, this is known as your replacement attorneys working ‘jointly for some decisions and jointly and severally for others’.
when-capacity-lost: Only when I do not have mental capacity
peopleToNotifyAboutYourLpa: People to notify about your LPA
wantPeopleToNotify: Do you want to notify anyone about your LPA?
yesToNotifySomeoneAboutYourLpa: yes to notify someone about your LPA
wantPeopleToNotifyContent:
You can choose to notify up to 5 people about your LPA. Most people choose family members or close friends. These people can raise any concerns before your LPA is registered.

We call these ‘people to notify’. Having people to notify is optional.

If you choose to notify a person about your LPA, we’ll send them information as soon as we have received and checked your application.
jointlyDescription: that you want your attorneys to work together to make decisions
jointlyAndSeverallyDescription: that you want your attorneys to work together or separately to make decisions
jointlyForSomeSeverallyForOthersDescript: that you want your attorneys to work together on some decisions but can make other decisions separately
whatToDoIfYouHaveConcerns: what to do if they have concerns
findOutMoreAboutPeopleToNotifyLink: Find out more about people to notify (opens in a new tab).
whoWouldYouLikeNotify: Add a person to notify about your LPA
weCanNotifyUpTo5PeopleContent: We can notify up to 5 people about your LPA on your behalf.
doYouWantToAddAnotherPersonToNotify: Do you want to add another person to notify?
addedMaxPeople: You’ve now added the maximum number of people we can notify about your LPA. If you want to add someone else, you must remove a person you’ve already added.
yesToAddAnotherPersonToNotify: yes to add another person to notify
howToConfirmYourIdentityAndSign: How to confirm your identity and sign the LPA
howToConfirmYourIdentityAndSignIntro: There are 3 steps to signing your LPA. You must complete these steps in one go.
yourCertificateProviderMustBeWithYou: {{.CertificateProviderName}}, your certificate provider, must be with you in person when you complete these steps.
howToConfirmYourIdentityAndSignSteps:
1. Confirm your identity

This is so we can be sure it’s you that’s about to sign the LPA. It should take less than 5 minutes.

2. Discuss your LPA with {{.CertificateProviderFirstNames}}

You should meet in private. {{.AttorneysFullNames}} should not be there.

3. Sign your LPA

Sign your LPA online. We will then send {{.CertificateProviderFullName}} a unique code by text message, that they must enter to prove they were with you.
whatYoullNeedToConfirmYourIdentity: What you’ll need to confirm your identity
whatYoullNeedToConfirmYourIdentityConten:
To confirm your identity, you’ll need 3 things from this list.

  • Your passport
    This must be your current passport or one that expired less than 10 years ago. Your name on your passport must be the same as on your LPA.
  • Your driving licence
    This must be your current licence or one that expired less than 10 years ago. Your name and address on your licence must be the same as on your LPA.
  • A GOV.UK Account
    We’ll ask you to sign in to your account so we can confirm your name, address and date of birth. We will not see any other information about you.
  • Post Office EasyID
    Post Office EasyID is a secure digital app that lets you confirm your identity online. We’ll confirm your name, address and date of birth through Post Office EasyID. We will not see any other information Post Office EasyID holds about you.
  • A Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) account and your National Insurance Number
    We’ll check your details with DWP - they’ll confirm your name, address and date of birth. We will not see any other information about you.
  • A utility bill
    This must a gas, electric, broadband or landline phone bill issued within the last three months. Your name and address on the bill must be the same as on your LPA. You’ll need to upload a photo, scan or a PDF of the bill.
  • A council tax bill
    This must be for the current council tax year. Your name and address on the bill must be the same as on your LPA. You’ll need to upload a photo, scan or a PDF of the bill.
certificateProviderHasDeclared: Certificate provider has made their declaration
yourLegalRightsAndResponsibilitiesConten:
Before signing, you must read your legal rights and responsibilities.

How your attorneys should act

By signing your LPA, you are appointing your attorneys to make decisions for you.

Your attorneys must follow the Mental Capacity Act Code of Practice:

  • They must assume you can make your own decisions, unless it is established that you cannot do so.
  • They must help you to make as many of your own decisions as you can.
  • They must take all practical steps to help you make a decision. They must only treat you as unable to make a decision if they have not succeeded in helping you make a decision through those steps.
  • They must not treat you as unable to make a decision because you have made an unwise decision.
  • They must act and make decisions in your best interests when you are unable to make a decision.
  • Before they make a decision or act for you, they must consider any option that is less restrictive of your rights and freedom which might achieve the same outcome.

How your LPA can be used

  • When you sign your LPA, along with all your attorneys, replacement attorneys and certificate provider, you are forming a legal agreement between you (a deed).
  • Your LPA can only be used if it’s registered with the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG).
  • You can cancel your LPA at any time if you have mental capacity. Find out more about how to cancel your LPA.
  • Your attorneys cannot use your LPA to make changes to your will.
  • Your LPA will expire when you die.

Before signing, you must read your legal rights and responsibilities.

How your attorneys should act

By signing your LPA, you are appointing your attorneys to make decisions for you.

Your attorneys must follow the Mental Capacity Act Code of Practice:

  • They must assume you can make your own decisions, unless it is established that you cannot do so.
  • They must help you to make as many of your own decisions as you can.
  • They must take all practical steps to help you make a decision. They must only treat you as unable to make a decision if they have not succeeded in helping you make a decision through those steps.
  • They must not treat you as unable to make a decision because you have made an unwise decision.
  • They must act and make decisions in your best interests when you are unable to make a decision.
  • Before they make a decision or act for you, they must consider any option that is less restrictive of your rights and freedoms which might achieve the same outcome.

How your LPA can be used

  • When you sign your LPA, you are making a deed. This is a legal document which grants certain powers to your attorneys.
  • Your LPA can only be used once it is registered with the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG).
  • You can cancel your LPA at any time if you have mental capacity. Find out more about how to cancel your LPA.
  • Your attorneys cannot use your LPA to make changes to your will.
  • Your LPA will expire when you die.
whatHappensNextContent:
Meet and talk with the donor to confirm you have no concerns

The donor, {{ .DonorFullName }}, should get in touch with you to arrange a face-to-face meeting.

By the end of your meeting, you’ll need to have confidence that:

  • they understand the LPA they’re making and what it means
  • they are not being pressured to make this LPA by someone else
  • there is no fraud involved in the making of the LPA

You may wish to take some notes about your conversation. If we ever have any concerns, we may ask you to tell us more about the conversation you had with {{ .DonorFirstNames }}.

Witness the donor signing their LPA

You must witness {{ .DonorFirstNames }} signing their LPA in person.

If they sign on paper, you’ll need to sign on paper to witness their signature.

If they sign their LPA online, you’ll be sent a code by text message, which you’ll need to provide to {{ .DonorFirstNames }}. This is how you’ll prove you’ve witnessed their signature.

Provide your certificate

Once we’ve received their signed LPA, you’ll need to ‘provide your certificate’ by signing online. We’ll email you when it’s time for you to do this.
provideTheCertificateForThisLpa: Provide the certificate for this LPA
provideTheCertificateForThisLpaContent:
When you confirm and sign, you are ‘providing the certificate’ for this LPA.

If you have any concerns, you should not sign. Instead, you should report a concern to the OPG.

Your statement as the certificate provider

I confirm that:

  • I’m aged 18 or over
  • I have read this LPA, including the legal rights and responsibilities of the donor and their attorney(s)
  • I am not acting as an attorney or a replacement attorney on this LPA
  • there is nothing that stops me from acting as the certificate provider on this LPA
  • I have either known the donor personally for at least 2 years or I am someone with the relevant professional skills to provide the certificate for this LPA

I certify that, as far as I’m aware, at the time of signing:

  • the donor understands the purpose of this LPA and the power it gives their attorneys (this means they were able to understand and remember this information, use it to make their decisions and communicate them)
  • no fraud or undue pressure is influencing the donor to create this LPA
  • there is nothing else which would prevent this LPA from being created
iAgreeToTheseStatements: I, {{.FullName}}, agree these statements are true and understand that ticking this box acts as my legal signature.
toSignAsCertificateProvider: the box to sign as the certificate provider
pageNotFoundContent:
If you typed the web address, check it is correct.

If you pasted the web address, check you copied the entire address.

Please use your browser to go back to the previous page, or return to the start page.
sorryProblem: Sorry, there is a problem with the service
beACertificateProvider: Be a certificate provider on a lasting power of attorney (LPA)
beACertificateProviderContent:
A certificate provider is an independent person who talks to the person making the LPA (the ‘donor’) to check they understand it and want to make it.

They must sign to confirm this. This is called providing the certificate.

What certificate providers do

Certificate providers should speak to the donor privately before they sign the LPA.

They need to check:

  • the donor understands their decision to make an LPA and the powers it gives to their attorneys
  • that nobody is putting pressure on them and that there has been no fraud in the making of the LPA
  • there is no other reason for concern

They will then sign to provide the certificate. They must also witness the donor signing their LPA, in person.

You do not need any legal knowledge to be a certificate provider.

If you have any concerns

You’ll need to report any concerns you have about an LPA.

Who can be a certificate provider

It’s up to the person making the LPA to choose a certificate provider. Most people ask a friend, neighbour or a colleague.

You can only be a certificate provider if you:

  • are not related to the donor or their attorney(s)
  • are over the age of 18
  • have known the donor well for at least 2 years, or you have the relevant professional skills

Before you start

If you’ve been asked to be someone’s certificate provider, you’ll need:

  • to sign in using GOV.UK One Login (the new way to sign into all government services)
  • to provide some of your details, so we can check your identity
  • a mobile phone, so we can send you a code when you’re with the donor

If you’ve not used GOV.UK One Login before, you can set up your account on the next page.
beACertificateProviderPostStartContent:
Professional certificate providers

If you work in an organisation where you’ll process multiple LPAs in batches, for example charities or large law firms, you’ll need to use our service for professional certificate providers.

confirmYourIdentityContent:
As a certificate provider, you act as a safeguard for the person making the LPA. Because of this, we need to be sure it’s you before you provide the certificate for this LPA.

What you’ll need

To confirm your identity you’ll need 2 things from this list:

  • Your passport
    This must be your current passport or one that expired less than 10 years ago. Your name on your passport must be the same as on your LPA.
  • Your driving licence
    This must be your current licence or one that expired less than 10 years ago. Your name and address on your licence must be the same as on your LPA.
  • A GOV.UK Account
    We’ll ask you to sign in to your account so we can confirm your name, address and date of birth. We will not see any other information about you.
  • Post Office EasyID
    Post Office EasyID is a secure digital app that lets you confirm your identity online. We’ll confirm your name, address and date of birth through Post Office EasyID. We will not see any other information Post Office EasyID holds about you.
  • A Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) account and your National Insurance Number
    We’ll check your details with DWP - they’ll confirm your name, address and date of birth. We will not see any other information about you.
  • A utility bill
    This must a gas, electric, broadband or landline phone bill issued within the last three months. Your name and address on the bill must be the same as on your LPA. You’ll need to upload a photo, scan or a PDF of the bill.
  • A council tax bill
    This must be for the current council tax year. Your name and address on the bill must be the same as on your LPA. You’ll need to upload a photo, scan or a PDF of the bill.
18OrOverWarning: You must be aged 18 or over to be a certificate provider
enterYourUkMobileContext: We need your mobile number so we can send you a code to use when you witness the donor signing their LPA.
youAreUnder18Error: You’ve entered a date of birth that means you are under 18, you must be 18 to be a certificate provider
weHaveIdentifiedYourCertificateProviderR: We have identified your certificate provider reference number
whoIsEligibleToBeCertificateProvider: Who is eligible to be a certificate provider
whoIsEligibleToBeCertificateProviderCont:
Before you continue, it’s important to check that you can be a certificate provider.

To be {{ .DonorFullNamePossessive }} certificate provider, you must either:

  • have known the donor, {{ .DonorFirstName }}, personally for at least 2 years (for example, as a friend or neighbour)
  • or be someone with the relevant professional skills to make sure the donor understands their LPA and wants to make it
whoIsEligibleToBeCertificateProviderDeta: Examples of who could act as a professional certificate provider

People with the relevant professional skills could include:

  • registered health care professionals
  • barristers, solicitors or advocates called or admitted in the UK
  • registered social workers
  • independent mental capacity advocates
whoCannotBeCertificateProvider: Who cannot be a certificate provider
whoCannotBeCertificateProviderContent:
You cannot be the certificate provider for this LPA if you are:

  • under 18 years old
  • an attorney or replacement attorney named in this LPA (or in any other LPA or enduring power of attorney for {{ .DonorFirstName }})
  • an attorney on a revoked LPA for {{ .DonorFirstName }}
  • related to {{ .DonorFirstName }} or one of their attorneys (this includes step-relations, in-laws, husbands, wives, partners, boyfriends and girlfriends, whether or not they live at the same address)
  • a business partner or employee of {{ .DonorFirstName }} or one of their attorneys
  • someone who works for a care home where {{ .DonorFirstName }} lives, or is a relative of someone working there
  • a director or an employee of a trust corporation owned by one of {{ .DonorFirstNamePossessive }} attorneys
  • anyone the Court of Protection does not think is independent enough
ifAnyStatementsApplyYouCannotBeACertific: If any of these statements apply to you, you cannot be the certificate provider for this LPA.

youveProvidedTheCertificateForThisLpa: You’ve provided the certificate for this LPA
certificateProvidedContent:
You have now signed and provided the certificate for this LPA.

This means you’ve done everything you need to do as {{ .DonorFirstNamesPossessive }} certificate provider.

What happens next

If the Office of the Public Guardian ever has any concerns about {{ .DonorFirstNamesPossessive }} LPA in future, we may contact you.

If you ever need to report a concern, you can do this at any time using the report a concern about an LPA service.

• I’m aged 18 or over.
  • I have read this lasting power of attorney (LPA) or had it read to me. This includes my legal rights and responsibilities.
  • I have a duty to act based on the principlies of the Mental Capacity Act 2005 and with consideration of the Mental Capacity Act Code of Practice.

I only have the authority to act under this LPA after an original attorney’s appointment is terminated. I must notify the Public Guardian if this happens.
beAnAttorneyContent:
What is an LPA?

A lasting power of attorney (LPA) is a legal document that lets someone (the ‘donor’) choose one or more trusted people (‘attorneys’) to make decisions on their behalf.

What attorneys do

You can make decisions on someone’s behalf if they appoint you using a lasting power of attorney (LPA).

The person who appoints you is called the ‘donor’. The person acting on the donor’s behalf is called the ‘attorney’.

The decisions you make will be for either the donor’s property and affairs or personal welfare, depending on the type of LPA they’ve made. They can choose you to be an attorney for both.

You do not need any legal experience to act as someone’s attorney but you must understand what the donor’s LPA means and always:

  • act based on the principles of the Mental Capacity Act 2005 and with consideration of the Mental Capacity Act code of practice
  • make any decisions in the donor’s best interests
  • help the donor make their own decisions as much as they can
  • follow any restrictions the donor put in their LPA
  • consider any conditions the donor put in their LPA

Find out how to make decisions for someone else including how to get help making difficult decisions and act in someone’s best interests. Your decisions can be checked.

You cannot act as an attorney until the LPA has been registered with the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG).

Who can be an attorney

It’s up to the person making the LPA to choose their attorneys. They can have as many attorneys as they like. If there’s more than one attorney, the donor will state in their LPA how their attorneys should make decisions.

Attorneys must:

  • be aged 18 or over
  • have mental capacity
  • not be on the Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) barred list
  • not be a subject to an ongoing bankruptcy order or a debt relief order (for a property and financial affairs LPA only)

Replacement attorneys

The person making an LPA can choose people to step in if one of their original attorneys can no longer act. The OPG must be told if this happens so the LPA can be updated and can continue to be used.

Before you start

If you’ve been asked to be someone’s attorney, you’ll need:

  • to sign in using GOV.UK One Login (the new way to sign in to all government services)
  • to provide some of your details, so we can check they match the information the donor has provided

If you’ve not used GOV.UK One Login before, you can set up your account on the next page.
weHaveIdentifiedYourAttorneyReferenceNum: We have identified your attorney reference number
weHaveIdentifiedYourReplacementAttorneyR: We have identified your replacement attorney reference number
attorneyCodeOfConductPfa:
As a property and affairs attorney, you’ll have the power to make decisions about the donor’s ({{.DonorFullNamePossessive}}) money and property. This could include managing bank accounts, bills and benefits, and selling property.

Before agreeing to become {{.DonorFirstNamesPossessive}} attorney, it’s important to understand how you should act when making decisions and using the LPA.

You must follow the principles of the Mental Capacity Act (2005) and the Mental Capacity Act Code of Practice.

This includes:

  • making sure that your decisions are in the best interests of the donor
  • not benefiting from any decisions you make
  • supporting the donor to make their own decisions wherever possible
  • making decisions yourself unless the donor has said otherwise
  • acting and making decisions as set out by the donor in their LPA
  • respecting the donor’s confidentiality
  • keeping records of the donor’s money and property - your decisions can be checked
  • keeping the donor’s money and property separate from your own

When you can no longer act as an attorney

If you misuse the donor’s money and they become bankrupt, you will no longer be able to act as their attorney.

You should inform the donor and the Office of the Public Guardian if you choose to stop being an attorney.

There are other reasons your appointment may be terminated (ended).
attorneyCodeOfConductHw:
As a personal welfare attorney, you’ll have the power to make decisions about the donor’s ({{.DonorFullNamePossessive}}) daily routine and personal and medical care.

Before agreeing to become {{.DonorFirstNamesPossessive}} attorney, it’s important to understand how you should act when making decisions and using the LPA.

You must follow the principles of the Mental Capacity Act (2005) and the Mental Capacity Act Code of Practice.

This includes:

  • making sure that your decisions are in the best interests of the donor
  • applying a duty of care when making any decisions
  • supporting the donor to make their own decisions wherever possible
  • making decisions yourself unless the donor has said otherwise
  • acting and making decisions as set out by the donor in their LPA
  • respect the donor’s confidentiality

When you can no longer act as an attorney

You should inform the donor and the Office of the Public Guardian if you choose to stop being an attorney.

There are other reasons your appointment may be terminated (ended).
replacementAttorneyCodeOfConductPfa:
As a replacement attorney, you will not be able to act on behalf of the donor ({{.DonorFullName}}) immediately. It is possible you may not be needed to act at all. However, it’s still important to understand how you should make decisions in case you ever need to.

As a property and affairs attorney, you’ll have the power to make decisions about the donor’s money and property. This could include managing bank accounts, bills and benefits, and selling property.

You must follow the principles of the Mental Capacity Act (2005) and the Mental Capacity Act Code of Practice.

This includes:

  • making sure that your decisions are in the best interests of the donor
  • not benefiting from any decisions you make
  • supporting the donor to make their own decisions wherever possible
  • making decisions yourself unless the donor has said otherwise
  • acting and making decisions as set out by the donor in their LPA
  • respecting the donor’s confidentiality
  • keeping records of the donor’s money and property - your decisions can be checked
  • keeping the donor’s money and property separate from your own

When you can no longer act as an attorney

If you misuse the donor’s money and they become bankrupt, you will no longer be able to act as their attorney.

You should inform the donor and the Office of the Public Guardian if you choose to stop being an attorney.

There are other reasons your appointment may be terminated (ended).
replacementAttorneyCodeOfConductHw:
As a replacement attorney, you will not be able to act on behalf of the donor ({{.DonorFullName}}) immediately. It is possible you may not be needed to act at all. However, it’s still important to understand how you should make decisions in case you ever need to.

As a personal welfare attorney, you’ll have the power to make decisions about the donor’s daily routine and personal and medical care.

You must follow the principles of the Mental Capacity Act (2005) and the Mental Capacity Act Code of Practice.

This includes:

  • making sure that your decisions are in the best interests of the donor
  • applying a duty of care when making any decisions
  • supporting the donor to make their own decisions wherever possible
  • making decisions yourself unless the donor has said otherwise
  • acting and making decisions as set out by the donor in their LPA
  • respecting the donor’s confidentiality

When you can no longer act as an attorney

You should inform the donor and the Office of the Public Guardian if you choose to stop being an attorney.

There are other reasons your appointment may be terminated (ended).
jointlyAndSeverallyExplanation:
Attorneys can make decisions together or on their own.

This means attorneys can share tasks and responsibilities. It also means that if one of the attorneys is unable to act, decisions can still be made without them.

In legal terms, this is known as acting ‘jointly and severally’.
jointlyExplanation:
All attorneys must agree on every decision, however big or small.

This means if one of the attorneys can no longer act, none of the other attorneys will be able to act either, unless the donor has stated otherwise in their restrictions. It also means that if the attorneys cannot agree on a decision, it cannot be made without going to court.

In legal terms, this is known as attorneys working ‘jointly’.
jointlyForSomeSeverallyForOthersExplanat:
All attorneys must agree on some decisions but can make other decisions on their own. The donor will state which decisions need to be agreed together.

In legal terms, this is known as your attorneys working ‘jointly for some decisions, and jointly and severally for other decisions’.
replacementJointlyAndSeverallyExplanatio:
Replacement attorneys can make decisions together or on their own.

This means replacement attorneys can share tasks and responsibilities. It also means that if one of the replacement attorneys is unable to act, decisions can still be made without them.

In legal terms, this is known as acting ‘jointly and severally’.
replacementJointlyExplanation:
All replacement attorneys must agree on every decision, however big or small.

This means if one of the replacement attorneys can no longer act, none of the other replacement attorneys will be able to act either, unless the donor has stated otherwise in their restrictions. It also means that if the replacement attorneys cannot agree on a decision, it cannot be made without going to court.

In legal terms, this is known as replacement attorneys working ‘jointly’.
replacementJointlyForSomeSeverallyForOth:
All replacement attorneys must agree on some decisions but can make other decisions on their own. The donor will state which decisions need to be agreed together.

In legal terms, this is known as your replacement attorneys working ‘jointly for some decisions, and jointly and severally for other decisions’.
whatIsYourUkMobileNumber: What is your UK mobile number?
youCanChooseToTellUsYourMobileNumber: You can choose to tell us your mobile number in case we ever need to contact you.
attorneyRightsAndResponsibilitiesContent:
Before signing, you must read your legal rights and responsibilities as an attorney.

How attorneys should act

When the donor signs their LPA, they are appointing their attorneys to make decisions for them.

As an attorney, you must follow the Mental Capacity Act Code of Practice:

  • You must assume the donor can make their own decisions, unless it is established that they cannot do so.
  • You must help the donor to make as many of their own decisions as they can.
  • You must take all practical steps to help the donor make a decision. You must only treat the donor as unable to make a decision if you have not succeeded in helping the donor make a decision through those steps.
  • You must not treat the donor as unable to make a decision because they have made an unwise decision.
  • You must act and make decisions in the donor’s best interests when they are unable to make a decision.
  • Before you make a decision or act for the donor, you must consider any option that is less restrictive of the donor’s rights and freedom which might achieve the same outcome.

How this LPA can be used

  • When the donor signs their LPA, along with all their attorneys, replacement attorneys and certificate provider, they are forming a legal agreement (a deed).
  • This LPA can only be used if it’s registered with the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG).
  • The donor can cancel their LPA at any time if they have mental capacity.
  • You, or any other attorney named in this LPA, cannot use the LPA to make changes to the donor’s will.
  • This LPA will expire when the donor dies.
whatHappensWhenYouSignTheLpaTitle: What happens when you sign the LPA
whatHappensWhenYouSignTheLpaContentAttor:
Signing the LPA is an important and powerful legal step.

When you sign, you’re officially saying that you want to be an attorney on {{ .DonorFullNamePossessive }} personal welfare LPA.

This means that once the LPA has been registered, you (and any other attorneys named in this LPA) can make decisions about:

Signing the LPA is an important and powerful legal step.

When you sign, you’re officially saying that you want to be an attorney on {{ .DonorFullNamePossessive }} property and affairs LPA.

This means that once the LPA has been registered, you (and any other attorneys named in this LPA) have the power to:
whatHappensWhenYouSignTheLpaContentRepla:
Signing the LPA is an important and powerful legal step.

When you sign, you’re saying that you want to be a replacement attorney on {{ .DonorFullNamePossessive }} personal welfare LPA.

This means that once the LPA has been registered, if you’re required to step in for an original attorney, can make decisions about:

Signing the LPA is an important and powerful legal step.

When you sign, you’re saying that you want to be a replacement attorney on {{ .DonorFullNamePossessive }} property and affairs LPA.

This means that once the LPA has been registered, if you’re required to step in for an original attorney, have the power to:
pwDecisionsBullets:
• their personal and medical care
  • their daily routine, for example washing, dressing and eating
  • their medical care
  • where they live
paPowersBullets:
• help the donor, {{ .DonorFirstNames }}, make decisions about their money or property, or make decisions for them if they do not have the mental capacity to make it themselves
  • deal with organisations, like their bank and utility companies, on their behalf
pwWhatHappensWhenYouSignWarning: While the donor still has mental capacity, you and any other attorneys cannot act on their behalf.
paWhatHappensWhenYouSignWarning: While the donor still has mental capacity, you and any other attorneys should only do these things if the donor asks you to.
youveFormallyAgreedToBeAttorney: You’ve formally agreed to be an attorney
youveFormallyAgreedToBeReplacementAttorn: You’ve formally agreed to be a replacement attorney
youveFormallyAgreedToBeAttorneyContent:
You’ve now signed and are named in {{.DonorFullNamePossessive}} LPA as an attorney.

The LPA will be submitted for registration when all the attorneys (and any replacement attorneys) have signed.
youveFormallyAgreedToBeReplacementAttorn:
You’ve now signed and are named in {{.DonorFullNamePossessive}} LPA as a replacement attorney.

As a replacement attorney, you do not need to edo anything else until one of the original attorneys can no longer act.

If this happens, you’ll need to contact the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG) to tell us you’ve stepped in.
attorneyWhatHappensNextContent:
What happens next

If the OPG has any concerns about {{.DonorFirstNamesPossessive}} LPA in future, we may contact you.

If you ever need to report a concern, you can do this at any time using the report a concern about an LPA service.
youMustSelectTheBoxToSignAttorney: You must select the box to sign as an attorney
youMustSelectTheBoxToSignReplacementAtto: You must select the box to sign as a replacement attorney
useAnAddressYouAlreadyEntered: Use an address you’ve already entered
thisIsAnImportantDecision: This is an important decision and should be thought about carefully.
lifeSustainingTreatmentContent:
You must choose whether your attorneys can give or refuse consent to life-sustaining treatment on your behalf.

Life-sustaining treatment means care, surgery, medicine or other help from doctors that’s needed to keep you alive.

Decisions about life-sustaining treatment can be needed in unexpected circumstances, such as a routine operation that did not go as planned
ifYouDoGiveAttorneysAuthority: If you do choose to give your attorneys the authority to make these decisions, you can restrict how they do this on the next page.
optionAHint: If you choose this option, your attorneys can speak to doctors on your behalf as if they were you.
optionBHint: If you choose this option, your attorneys cannot speak to doctors as if they were you. Doctors will make any decisions about life-sustaining treatment. However, they may still take into account the views of your attorneys and other people interested in your welfare, as well as any written statement you’ve made.
examplesOfLifeSustainingTreatmentDetails:
Whether a treatment is life-sustaining depends on the situation. If you had pneumonia, a simple course of antibiotics could be life-sustaining.

Other examples include:

  • a serious operation, such as a heart bypass or organ transplant
  • cancer treatment
  • artificial nutrition or hydration (food or water given other than by mouth)
doYouWantYourAttorneysToMakeDecisionsAbo: Do you want your attorneys to make decisions about life-sustaining treatment?
iGiveMyAttorneysAuthorityLifeSustainingT: I give my attorneys authority to give or refuse consent to life-sustaining treatment on my behalf.
iDoNotGiveMyAttorneysAuthorityLifeSustai: I do not give my attorneys the authority to give or refuse consent to life-sustaining treatment on my behalf.
